Dreyer's Grand Ice Cream is proud to inform all interested parties that our company is complying with OSHA's Process Safety Management Standard (PSM), Title 29 Code of Federal Regulations 1910.119, EPA's Risk Management Program regulations (RMP), Title 40 CFR Part 68, and other state and local codes applicable to our facility and process. We have undertaken this process to deal with the risks involved with the storage, handling, and use of Anhydrous Ammonia in our facility. Our goal is to promote worker, public, and plant safety!


This is a 5 year RMP submittal for the Dreyer's Grand Ice Cream facility, located at 3426 Wells Street, Fort Wayne, Indiana. We manufacture some of the finest packaged ice cream and ice cream snacks in the world. Some of the equipment in the facility includes processing tanks, piping, packaging equipment, raw materials, warehousing, two ammonia refrigeration engine rooms (process and warehouse), refrigerated storage, boilers, and miscellaneous utilities. Also located at the facility is raw milk processing equipment, shipping and receiving docks, and a waste water treatment equalization system. The facility produces and ships millions of pounds of products each year.


The refrigeration systems required for our facility necessitates the submission of this Risk Management Plan. The process refrigeration system contains in excess of 45,353 pounds of anhydrous ammonia while the warehouse refrigeration system contains in excess of 52,333 pounds of anhydrous ammonia. The site therefore has a total of 97,686 pounds of ammonia. This surpasses the threshold quantity of 10,000 pounds outlined in Process Safety Management and Risk Management Program regulations.


Dreyer's Grand Ice Cream has implemented numerous policies and procedures to enable our facility to prevent the occurrence, and minimize the consequences of, significant releases of Anhydrous Ammonia to the atmosphere. The plant also has many policies and procedures to minimize the potenti

al for catastrophic accidents involving around any other hazardous substances, fires, or explosions., and other types of catastrophic accidents.


Our safety programs focus on the rules, procedures, and practices that govern individual processes, activities, or pieces of equipment. These rules are detailed and improved as necessary. They are also communicated to and accepted by all employees at our facility.


DESCRIPTION OF THE EMERGENCY RESPONSE PLAN

In the event that an ammonia leak is detected, employees are to notify the onsite Refrigeration Technicians, who are Hazmat Responders. The site also has numerous ammonia detector devices located throughout the facility that would alert employees, and especially the Refrigeration Technicians, of a leak. The detector ppm levels are displayed in the ammonia engine room control room. The Hazmat Responder takes an ammonia level reading using a detection device. If the Hazmat Responder determines that the ammonia level is above 35 ppm, an evacuation of the exposure area is ordered. If an evacuation is necessary, an Incident Commander takes control of the situation.


The Hazmat Responder and/or Incident Commander will determines if the leak is serious enough that outside assistance is needed. If outside assistance is needed, the local HAZMAT organization is contacted and the internal Hazmat/Emergency Response Team is mobilized. 

The Hazmat Responders then take appropriate action to mitigate the leak. They are trained in plant procedures, such as Emergency Shutdown Standard Operating Procedures (SOP's), to control the leak with appropriate personal protective devices in place.


Dreyer's Grand Ice Cream is committed to continuous improvement of our policies, procedures, and facility. It is the intention of Dreyer's Grand Ice Cream to remain an industry leader, especially in safety. New technology, training techniques, and equipment are continuously being added to our system. As part of ongoing training, Dreyer's Hazmat re

sponders train with the local HAZMAT responders (Fort Wayne Fire Department) at our facility.


PSM PROGRAM

Dreyer's Grand Ice Cream has organized the information and polices pertaining to the refrigeration process into a complete PSM library consisting of nine numbered volumes. Some of these volume numbers are assigned to sets of reference manuals, such as Operation and Maintenance manuals. This library also incorporates the use of videos and computerized tests. A description is as follows:


Volume IA of the PSM/RMP Library incorporates mainly policies, including the following:


Employee Participation Guidelines: This policy outlines the commitment between management and employees to establish a program for a successful and safe program.


Process Safety Information: This includes information on the ammonia inventory at the facility, applicable codes, design standards, and information pertaining to the hazards of ammonia (referenced from the IIAR ammonia Data Book).


Process Hazard Analysis Program: This program outlines a thorough, orderly, systematic approach for identifying, evaluating, and controlling potential hazards within a process involving potentially hazardous chemicals such as ammonia.


Training: Dreyer's Grand Ice Cream has implemented a robust training program for all of the Refrigeration Technicians. The plan is for 100% of the Refrigeration Technicians to be RETA CIRO certified, which at this time the facility has 9 of our current staff of 10 certified with one still in training. In addition, the training includes videos, tests, hands on demonstrations, SOP reviews, etc.


Contractor Qualification Guidelines: This guideline has been established to verify that the contractors working in the facility are qualified to work on the system, trained in the hazards associated with their work, and made aware of the hazards presented by the facility to the employees of the contractor. Management of Change and Pre-Startup Safety Review Programs: These pro

grams have been developed to monitor and provide a "check and balance" system to monitor changes in the facility and to verify that changes are safe and consistent with company policy.


Ammonia Line Break Program: This has been developed to ensure that the system is safe to work on whenever maintenance is needed. It includes the ammonia system, but also includes compressed air, chemicals, natural gas, steam, etc. The line break permit must be used whenever any work is done in this area.


Ammonia Work Procedure: The plant has many requirements that must be met whenever work is done on the ammonia system, and are included in this section. This includes communication, work order details, personal protective equipment (PPE), oil draining process, etc.


Many more specific programs and policies (Hot Work, Confined Space, Lockout / Tagout, additional Employee training, etc.) have been developed. For information specific to these see the Safety, Health, and Environmental Manager or the Industrial Services Manager.


Volume II incorporates information on the specific system components of the production area refrigeration equipment. This information is used as a reference source for the operator to positively identify system components. This manual also provides a checklist for performing the yearly Mechanical Integrity Inspection.


Volume III incorporates a complete valve list, process and instrumentation diagrams, flow schematics, and other drawing pertinent to the production area refrigeration equipment. The valve list contains information on the type, port , identifying number, use, location, model, manufacturer, drawing reference, and normal operating position of each valve in the system. Process and Instrumentation Diagrams (P&ID's) are included for the individual system components. Flow schematics are included showing the entire system. A Block flow diagram provides a brief overview of the system. Drawings are included showing symbol and abbreviation descriptions.

Plan views are included to allow the operator to physically locate equipment in the building.


Volume IV incorporates a complete set of standard Operating Procedures (SOP's) for the production area refrigeration equipment, describing the proper steps for preparing components for start-up, starting components, monitoring normal operation, shutting down as part of normal operation, restarting equipment as part of normal operation, shutting down equipment for maintenance, restarting equipment after maintenance, shutting down equipment in emergency situations, restarting equipment after an emergency situations shutdown, and pump-out procedures. Each Standard Operating Procedure also includes the Technical Operating Specifications, possible consequences of deviation from standard operating procedures, and lock-out/tag-out procedures. Volume V contains Operation and Maintenance Information for the production area refrigeration equipment including manufacturer's information, spare parts list, maintenance procedures, and preventative maintenance procedures.


Volume VI incorporates information on the specific system components of the warehouse refrigeration equipment (similar to Volume II).


Volume VII incorporates a complete valve list, process and instrumentation diagrams, flow schematics, and other drawing pertinent to the warehouse area refrigeration equipment (similar to Volume III).


Volume VIII incorporates a complete set of standard operating procedures for the warehouse area refrigeration equipment (similar to Volume IV).


Volume IX contains Operation and Maintenance Information for the warehouse area refrigeration equipment including manufactures information, spare parts list, maintenance procedures, and preventative maintenance procedures (similar to Volume V).


A full Process Hazard Analysis was performed in April 2020 for the Process refrigeration system. The PHA team made several recommendations to improve safety and operations. These items have been prio

ritized and addressed as part of the continuous improvement of the facility. Dreyers Fort Wayne performs PHAs every 5 years or as required as part of the PSM MOC program.  

A full Process Hazard Analysis was performed in November 2018 for the Warehouse refrigeration system. The PHA team made recommendations to improve safety and operations. These items have been addressed as part of the continuous improvement of the facility. 

Addendum PHAs were performed in February 2021 and December 2022 for the changes/additions made to the Refrigeration System Upgrade Projects under the MOC Program. This encompassed changes to both the Warehouse and Process Refrigeration Systems. The PHA team made recommendations to improve safety and operations. These items have been prioritized and addressed as part of the continuous improvement of the facility.

Dreyer's Grand Ice Cream ammonia refrigeration system also incorporates additional safety items such as tagging of all valves and components, ammonia detection system, a robust PM system, and a PC / PLC based control system with a graphical operator interface that controls mitigating devices such as emergency exhaust fans, emergency shutdown systems and alarms. Dreyer's Grand Ice Cream also records and investigates any and all ammonia leaks, no matter how minor. Root causes are determined, and counter measures such as preventative maintenance (PM's) are implemented in order to prevent any future occurrences.


DESCRIPTION OF THE PRODUCTION AREA REFRIGERATION SYSTEM

The Dreyer's Grand Ice Cream production system operates separately from the warehouse system described below. The production facility incorporates a standard evaporation Evaporation and Compression Style Ammonia Refrigeration system. Ammonia vapor from the Intercoolers is routed to the suction inlet of the High Stage Compressors.


At the High Stage Compressors, ammonia vapor is compressed to a super heated vapor. The super heated vapor is fed to the Evaporative Conde

nsers. At the Condensers the super heated vapor rejects heat and converts to high pressure Condensed Liquid Drain. The condenser accomplishes this by using a combination of air and water flow across ammonia coils. The condensers are equipped with Hydrostatic Relief valves that relieve around the isolation valves. Airflow is supplied to the condensers via fans internal to each condenser.


Water from the Condenser Water Sump is pumped via the Condenser Pumps to the Evaporative Condensers. At the Condenser the water is forced through spray nozzles over the ammonia coils. Water is collected at the bottom of the Condenser in a sump pan where it gravity drains back to the Condenser Water Sump. From here it is re-circulated back to the condensers. As the water level of the Condenser Water Sump lowers it trips a Water Makeup Float, which opens allowing water makeup to refill the Condenser Sump Tank. The Condenser Water Sump is also equipped with an Ozone Generator for the control of contaminates in the water system. A Sight Glass mounted on the Water Sump Tank allows the operator to see the correct water level in the sump tank.


The Condensed Liquid Drain, from the Evaporative Condensers, gravity drains to the Thermosyphon Vessels.


High Pressure Liquid gravity drains from the Thermosyphon Vessels to Thermosyphon Supply Headers, which supply liquid to the Thermosyphon Oil Coolers of the High Stage and the Low Stage Compressors. At the Thermosyphon Oil Coolers on the Compressors, the High Pressure Liquid absorbs heat from the oil pumped through the Compressor. As it absorbs heat, it changes from a liquid to a Liquid/Vapor Combination. This Liquid Vapor Combination is returned from the Thermosyphon Oil Cooler on each Compressor, to the Thermosyphon Return Header, where it returns to the Thermosyphon Vessels. In the Thermosyphon Vessels the liquid and vapor is separated. The liquid being is re-circulated back out to the Compressors. The Vapor is fed to the Evaporative Conde

essors.


High Pressure Liquid from the Filter Assembly is also fed to several evaporators throughout the production area. As the liquid ammonia passes through the coil, it absorbs heat from the air, changing state from a liquid to a vapor. The vapor from these evaporators is piped back to the intercoolers or the Suction Traps.


The system is also equipped with two heat exchangers which, utilizing high stage discharge, heat a glycol solution which is then piped under the freezer floors to prevent a buildup of permafrost. In the Heat Exchangers, the vapor rejects heat thus condensing to a liquid, where it collects on the bottom of the Heat Exchangers and drains back into the High Stage Suction Main.


The Liquid from the Low Temperature Re-circulators is pumped via Refrigerant Pumps to the Low Temperature Re-circulated Evaporators. Low Temperature Re-circulated Suction returns from the Low Temperature Evaporators to the Low Temperature Re-circulators, where the liquid and vapor separates. The liquid is pumped back to the Evaporators, and the vapor is compressed in the Low Stage Compressors. The compressed vapor from the Low Stage Compressors is discharged into a Common Low Stage Discharge Main where it is returned to the inlet of the Intercoolers.


The process refrigeration system is also equipped with an oil still, which allows for removal of oil from the system. A spring -to -close valve is installed on this vessel, to provide for safer oil draining. All refrigeration equipment have relief valves installed as required. Most are the dual-relief type with a three-way valve, although there are several smaller heat exchangers or oil pots where single relief valves are installed. These relief valves are on our pm program and replaced as required.


DESCRIPTION OF THE WAREHOUSE AREA REFRIGERATION SYSTEM

The Nestle Dreyer's Grand Ice Cream warehouse system operates separately from the production system described above. The facility incorporates a standard evaporation E

vaporation and Compression Style Ammonia Refrigeration system. Ammonia vapor, High Stage Suction, from the Intercooler is routed to the suction inlet of the High Stage Screw Compressors.


At the High Stage Compressors, ammonia vapor is compressed to a super heated vapor and fed to the Evaporative Condensers, where the vapor rejects heat and converts to high pressure Condensed Liquid. The condenser accomplishes this by using a combination of air and water flow across ammonia coils. The condensers are equipped with Hydrostatic Relief valves that relieve around the isolation valves. Airflow is supplied to the condensers via internal fans. Water is supplied to condensers via water pumps.


At the Condensers, the water is forced through spray nozzles over the ammonia coils and then collected in a sump pan. There, where it gravity drains back to the condenser water sump tank, where it is re-circulated back to the condensers. As the water level of the condenser water sump lowers, it trips a Water Makeup Float which opens allowing water makeup to refill the tank. The condenser water sump is also equipped with an Ozone Generator for the control of contaminates in the water system. A Sight Glass mounted on the Water Sump Tank allows the operator to see the correct water level in the tank. The Condensed Liquid Drain from the Evaporative Condensers gravity drains to the thermosyphon portion of the High Pressure Receiver.


High Pressure Liquid gravity drains from the thermosyphon portion of the Receiver to the Thermosyphon Oil Coolers of the Compressors. At the Thermosyphon Oil Coolers on the Compressors, the Liquid liquid absorbs heat from the oil pumped through the Compressor. As it absorbs heat, it changes from a liquid to a Liquid/Vapor Combination, which is returned from the Thermosyphon Oil Coolers to the Thermosyphon Portion of the High Pressure Receiver. There the liquid and vapor is separated, and the liquid is re-circulated back out to the Compressor Oil Coolers. The

Vapor is returned to the Evaporative Condensers, where it is re-condensed.


As liquid accumulates in the Thermosyphon Portion of the Receiver, it will overfill and gravity drain into the Receiver Portion of the Receiver, where it is stored until needed. As Ammonia Liquid is needed in the system, it is fed (by pressure) from the Receiver through Liquid Filters and then used to feed several Evaporators and as Liquid Makeup to several vessels.


High Pressure Liquid is fed to the Purger. Purged Gas is piped from the Purge Points at Evaporative Condenser to the Purger. The Automatic Gas Purger separates the ammonia from the noncondensable
by condensing the ammonia into a liquid. Any non-condensables are piped to a Water Bubbler to remove any traces of ammonia. Condensed Vapor is piped back to the Low Temperature Recirculator.


High Pressure Liquid is also fed to Intercooler as liquid make-up. The Intercooler receives Booster Discharge from the Low Stage Compressors and cools the discharge before going to the High Stage
Compressors. The liquid from the Intercooler is fed into the Low Temperature Recirculator. High Pressure Liquid from the Filter Assembly is also fed to the Charging Room Evaporators, and a Munters Unit on the Dock. As the liquid is passed through the coils, it absorbs heat from the air, changing from a liquid to a vapor. The Vapor from these Evaporators is piped back to the Intercooler.


Each Ammonia Compressor, the Low Temperature Recirculators, the Receiver, and the Intercooler, and oil pot are equipped with dual safety relief valves which are piped to Common Relief System. The transfer vessel is equipped with a single relief valve which is piped into the common Relief System. These relief valves are on our pm program and replaced as required. The Common Relief System is piped through the roof and is equipped with a rain cap.


Each Thermosyphon Oil Cooler is equipped with a single hydrostatic relief valve which is piped from the Oil Cooler into the

Oil Separator. The Thermosyphon Oil Coolers are also protected on the ammonia side by hydrostatic relief valves.


The warehouse system is equipped with an oil still, which allows oil to be removed from the system. A spring spring-to to-close valve is installed on this vessel vessel, to provide for safer oil draining. The system is equipped with a Heat Exchanger which, utilizing high stage discharge, heats a glycol solution, which is then piped under the freezer floors to prevent a buildup of permafrost. In the Heat Exchanger, the vapor rejects heat thus condensing to a liquid, where it collects on the bottom of the Heat Exchanger and is returned to the Intercooler.


The warehouse engine room has two Recirculators. One serves the storage evaporators while the other is designed for product hardeners. The Liquid from the Recirculator is pumped via sealed refrigeration pumps to various evaporators or hardeners. Low Temperature Recirculated Suction is returned to the Recirculator where the liquid and vapor separates. The liquid is then pumped back to the evaporators. The vapor is drawn into the Low Stage Compressors, where it is compressed. The compressed vapor is returned to the inlet of the Intercooler.


The Dry Suction from the Intercooler is compressed in the High Stage Compressors, and then discharged to the Condensers.

Low Temp Recirculated Liquid is pumped from the Recirculators to the Evaporators in Storage Box 4, Storage Box 6, the Warehouse Shipping Dock, and all of the snack line hardeners. While in the evaporator or hardener, the ammonia absorbs heat from the air and changes from a Liquid to a Liquid/Vapor Combination. The Liquid/Vapor Combination returns to the recirulator. These evaporators are equipped with a hot gas circuit, which is used for defrost. The defrost condensate returns back into High Stage Suction Main, where it is returned to the Intercooler.

The Transfer Vessel is used when there is a high liquid level in the Intercooler. Upon demand,

the liquid is returned to the Thermosyphon Vessel/Receiver, via hot gas pressure. 

SUMMARY OF THE FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

Dreyer's Grand Ice Cream, Fort Wayne, has had 1 reportable release of more than 100 pounds in a 24 hour period in the last 5 years. The following is a summary of the ammonia release that occurred on May 17, 2022:


The plant was expanding the capacity in the warehouse engine room to handle the future additions. TJW Industrial is the Refrigeration contractor that is performing the work. 

On Tuesday, May 17, 2022, TJW was staging parts for the next day. They used a forklift with a large mast to bring in parts into the warehouse engine room. While doing this task, the mast struck the thermosyphon supply line feeding the oil cooler for WLC-11 (OCWLC-11). When this piping moved, it created a crack in the Thermosyphon Supply (TSS) connection on the oil cooler OCWLC-11 which resulted in an ammonia release. 

The driver of the forklift and the spotter were able to escape without injury. The plants refrigeration personnel (Hazmat Responders) responded immediately and the leak was isolated completely within 28 minutes. The leak resulted in a release of 1,179.6 lbs of ammonia. No off-site impact was made.   

All notifications were made to the proper agencies. A complete leak investigation was assembled and a thorough investigation was completed. Several recommendations were made to prevent future occurrences, and these have since been implemented.  



PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

Nestle Dreyer's Grand Ice Cream holds monthly PSM team Meetings, led by the on-site Industrial Service Manager. The facility has OSHA Process Safety Management and EPA Risk Management Programs, and has a partnership with a local contractor, TJW Industrial, who specializes in these areas. The facility also has ongoing training, including a specialized training program for the Refrigeration techs that work on the ammonia system. Other items include annual Mechanical I

ntegrity Inspections, PSM/RMP Compliance Audits as required every 3 years, Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) as required, Emergency Response Training and Practice Drills, Management of Change Program,Lock-out/Tag-out Program, Hot Work Program, and the Line Break program. All programs are continuously reviewed and improved on a regular basis.

Dreyer's Grand Ice Cream is committed to safety of its employees and surrounding community.
